Posts.Content: May 24, 2013 04:01PM Capriness wrote: Rinneron, I really feel for you.  I wish I could hug you.  Stage IV has been the loneliest time of my life.  Every time I thought it was okay to tell a man that I was stage IV, he ran.  Even someone I considered my best friend of many years. I told him I wanted to start dating him and he refused but wouldn't say why. Well, I know why.  We all know why.  No one wants to get their heart broken by falling in love with someone who's going to die.  I even tried dating a man who had no arms thinking he'd understand the body issues.  But the "living" issues way outweighed the body issues and he ran too. I wish there was a dating club just for stage IV men and women.  Companionship is so necessary to living I think. Maybe I'll Google "Stage IV Dating Club" and see what pops up. I don't mean to bring you down Rinneron.  I just really hate this disease and how it strips us of everything that's meaningful. I know.  Not everything.  But I'm ranting now, too. {{{HUGS}}} Teri
Posts.Title: Really Rough Day rinneron sarajaneevans

Posts.Content: Capriness wrote: As some of you might remember I was in the hospital at the beginning of May because one of my lung mets had started to bleed into my lungs and was drowning me.  So they did rads to kill it.  Well I've been having the same symptoms and so last night got up the nerve to cough up some of the "phlegm" but it was like a blood clot.  It wasn't liquid blood like last time but it was way more than pink tinged mucous which was what my rad onc had said I would probably find. She said pink tinged or white mucous. Now I'm so worried again. I have a doctor appointment this morning for a stress echo to see if my heart is the reason I'm having such a hard time breathing. I'm going to keep the appointment but I have a feeling that my heart is not going to be the reason. When I emailed my rad onc yesterday I asked her what the percentage of success was for the rads to have worked on that tumor that was bleeding.  She said more than 70% success.  That sounded good last night.  Now I'm thinking it wasn't so good after all. Has anyone else had problems with their lung mets bleeding?  If so, please let me know the outcome or at least the treatments you went through because right now I don't see much in the way of available treatments. Thank you so much for your help -- as usual. Teri Teri Dx 7/23/1996, DCIS, 2cm, Stage IIB, 4/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 8/15/1996 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 9/15/1996 AC Hormonal Therapy 11/26/1996 Surgery 2/15/1997 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Surgery 5/15/1997 Reconstruction (left): Free TRAM flap, Nipple reconstruction; Reconstruction (right): Free TRAM flap, Nipple reconstruction Surgery 9/15/2005 Lymph node removal: Right, Underarm/Axillary Radiation Therapy 2/1/2006 Breast, Lymph nodes Chemotherapy 4/15/2006 Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Hormonal Therapy 6/15/2006 Arimidex (anastrozole) Hormonal Therapy 6/15/2006 Aromasin (exemestane) Hormonal Therapy 8/15/2006 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy 9/15/2006 Hormonal Therapy 7/15/2009 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Dx 8/15/2009, DCIS, 6cm+, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 1/15/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Targeted Therapy 2/7/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2014 02:13AM Capriness wrote: Susan, remember that I was also told I had 2 months left to go so I joined hospice.  It's now been 6 or 7 months.  They really don't know; they're only guessing.  Please remember that.  You're in control of your own well-being.  You can get a second opinion if you want. I did.  She told me the same thing: 2 months.  I think it's a a standard amount of time they give for certain states of disease. I will keep you wrapped warmly in my arms with {{{hugs}}} and surrounded by (((happy thoughts))).  Just relax and drink it in. We all love you so much. Teri

Posts.Title: Blood clots or DVT's K-Lo gonegirl

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2013 04:32PM Capriness wrote: Rozann, when my shortness of breath worsened and they couldn't attribute it to the lung mets they just said it must just be the cancer "progressing." After me pressing them enough because that's not a good enough answer for me, they finally told me it was lymphngitic spread. That means the cancer is no longer inside the mets but has gone into both the lungs' lymph systems and there is literally no treatment that will help. Hence, I'm in hospice. So if you don't like their answers, keep pushing. It may be they just don't want to tell you or don't think you can handle the truth or whatever. Teri

Loveforlife - I will ask my onc about Xeloda. Anything that can help my breathing would be a miracle! What are the SE's? Teri

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2013 09:52AM Capriness wrote: My hospice nurse gave me liquid ativan that I squirt under my tongue and it absorbs really quickly (10 minutes) and helps calm you and helps you sleep.  You might ask for that. As far as what you're going through, I'm sorry but my treatment doesn't even compare.  But I'm sure someone's will.  Hang in there.  Try to keep your mind occupied by watching a movie or something. Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2013 09:22AM Capriness wrote: I had no idea cancer caused blood clots until I got one in my leg that travelled to my lung and caused severe shortness of breath.  After doing research and talking to my onc, cancer gives off a protein that causes blood cells to stick together apparently.  So I'm on daily stomach injections of Arixtra for the rest of my life. I really wish they would come up with a pill instead of the injections though.  It's getting really tiring.  Luckily it's not too painful.
Posts.Title: Blood clots or DVT's K-Lo gonegirl

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2013 03:58PM Capriness wrote: Australia, I have mediastinal nodes.  I assume you want to hear the good with the bad.  From there it grew into my lungs and spread to create 8 lung mets. So please be careful when your onc is checking your lungs and make him be extra vigilant. Your mediastinal nodes run right down the middle of your lungs, heart, and esophagus.  My onc told me my heart was not an issue.  (It must be a rare place for cancer to spread.) But I do worry about my esophagus every time I have trouble swallowing. Congrats on your good results of treatment.  I hope it keeps working for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2013 06:57PM Capriness wrote: I always ask my onc for my life expectancy because I want his opinion based on his experience during his career, not based on statistics.  Your onc deals with this as his or her job and has a lot of knowledge based on your body type, fitness, and survival, etc.  It's okay to ask them.  If you really want to know that is.  I do.  I find it easier to plan my life.  I have already passed two of my onc's prognoses so, with everything else, no one ever knows for certain. So if you want to know, ask your doctor.  Don't rely on Google.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 05:56PM Capriness wrote:  1.You first began posting here on bco.org in February of this year, but stated that you have been fighting breast cancer since 1996. That is a long time indeed. What did that fight looked like for you? I was originally diagnosed with DCIS while serving in the Peace Corps in Costa Rica. My doctor recommended surgery, then chemo, then rads. I decided on chemo, then surgery and no rads.So I started out with A-C-T which was standard at the time.After I did chemo I had my bilateral mastectomies. I liked that I did that because when they did the original lumpectomy, the margins were dirty but when they did the mastectomies, the margins were clear.That told me that the chemo had obviously worked!Yay!!! 9 years later…dummm-da-dummm-dummm…Stage III, back in my chest wall, then 3 years later Stage IV in my lungs and here I am with all of you fine people!  2. Before you "retired" what kind of jobs did you have? I know that cancer cost you your last two positions, but I don't know what you did in your professional life. I was an accountant in my previous life.I had just earned my CMA which is like a CPA but instead of Certified Public Accountant it stands for Certified Management Accountant. I worked really hard and was being groomed for a Vice President of Finance job when “Corporate” found out about my cancer and pulled the rug out from under me.  3. Your online portfolio of artwork is quite breath-taking. Do you have any formal training as a visual artist or are you self-taught? What are your artistic inspirations? How did you find your studio partner? I am a self-taught artist but my body of work entails hundreds of paintings.The problem is it’s expensive to get them digitized to put on the web site so that people can buy prints of them.So I hardly have anything up.After I “go” my brother is going to hold a charity auction or something. I told him just not to give the proceeds to Komen. My studio partner, Sherrill, is my best friend of 38 years. She has turned out to be quite the artist too!  4. I haven't travelled around Oregon much. Just driven some of the coastline and gone to a conference in Portland. Can you tell us about Estacada, OR? Is is a rural area? Small towns? Is it flat or hilly? Can you see mountains or the ocean? Estacada is a very small town at the edge of the foothills of Mt Hood. The reason I moved out here was because it was the only place I could afford to buy acreage and I had just bought a horse off the race track that the owners were going to kill because he couldn’t race anymore. It’s a very cute little town and I fell in love with it right away. It’s on the Clackamas River which gets a lot of drunk and idiotic recreationers in the summer months.But in the winter I get lots of beautiful snow because I live “up river” from the town at 1,200’ elevation.So if you’ve been to Portland on a clear day, you’ve seen Mt. Hood and so you can sort of see me. (And maybe Deuce would be staring back at you from some bushes up here too!)  5. And finally, all of Deuce's fans want to know, how did you come to live with so many animals? How much land do you have to house them? Did you get a herd of goats or did you add them one by one? Did you milk them and make cheese or did they just wander about enjoying their lives? A few years after I moved up here my best friend’s cousin decided to move to Alaska and needed a home for his 2 female goats.They were Pepper and Casey (now deceased). I have 4 acres so plenty of room. I loved having goats so much I decided to breed the two girls so I got Jet and Martha out of Pepper, and I got Domino, Deuce, and Sunday (now deceased) out of Casey.And a farm was born. No milking – just loving.  6. Bonus question: Please tell us how you chose your screen name. For the first month, I envisioned short pants, but I bet there is something more in your choice than I imagine. My friends used to call me Goat-Woman.Capri is the latin root for goat.To be capricious is to act silly like a goat. Capricorn is the sign of the goat, etc.Then I just added something that sounded female on the end: -ness.Capriness.

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2013 10:39AM Capriness wrote: Hi everybody.  As some of you know I am going into hospice care right now because I decided to quit treatment back in 2006.  That was when I had my 2nd round of chemo and remembered that I swore I would never do chemo again after the 1st time. But then, I had forgotten this since there's no way to enter it in to the treatment section of BCO, I did a trial. My side effects were, once again, unbearable and I swore NEVER AGAIN! So this year my doctor tried a targeted therapy on me telling me it wasn't chemo. Afinitor.  The mouth ulcers and rash and zits all over my body made me realize it doesn't have to be called chemo.  My reason for not wanting chemo was so I could have a good QOL at the end. The point I want to make for this thread is that I made that decision back when I was still relatively healthy (of mind anyway).  Human nature makes us afraid of dying.  I knew if I waited until the doctor said, "Take this or you won't live another year," I would panic and take whatever he told me to.  If you've read my other post about this topic you'll recall that I did the same thing with my decision to have bilateral mastectomies. The surgeon gave me an out while we were in the operating suite but I said that although I was terrified of doing it, I had made the decision back when I was more mentally stable and I was going to stick with the decision. So far I haven't regretted any decision I've made over the years when I follow this principle. I wish you all luck when making your decisions. Teri

Has anyone had this type of MRI and if so, can you please explain better how it's done?  I'm being driven there so I'm going to take a double dose of clonazepam but I'm still scared to death. Thanks for any info.
